sub_title: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer
summary:
An award-winning wind energy enthusiast with 7 years of experience in the areas of wind turbine and wind farm flow control. ENFJ personality type that actively finds ways to make a positive impact on society through his strong sense of optimism and excellent problem-solving, organizational, social, management and analytical skills. Strongly believes human connection is key to success and therefore seeks to establish new and maintain existing relationships. Aims to create an inclusive working environment.

Since 2017, has been heavily involved with the design, implementation and analysis of wind farm control field experiments and related consultancy projects for leading industry partners. His research topics include wind farm flow control, wind farm modeling, yield assessment, flow estimation, turbine control, and optimization.

inventors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer
Full Professor bij Technische Universiteit Delft

awards.title: EAWE Young Doctor Award 2021
awards.description: EAWE awards every year the EAWE Excellent Young Doctor Award’ to a graduate Doctor who has defended a thesis of significant relevance for the further development of wind power and should demonstrate impact on future development and/or impact on the implementation of wind power.

awards.title: Best Student Paper Award
awards.description: Our publication received the Best Student Paper Award at the IEEE CCTA 2019 conference in Hong Kong, China.
awards.issuer: IEEE Conference on Control Technology and Applications (CCTA) 2019

awards.title: PhD Best Poster Award (1st place)
awards.description: This event required us to pitch our research topic to a committee of academic staff of the TU Delft in 60 seconds, supported by a self-made poster. The award was 1000 EUR, which was spent on a research visit to NREL in January-March 2017.

awards.title: Master's degree (nominal, cum laude)
awards.description: All courses in the master's programme of Systems & Control were passed at first attempt, in the assigned time (nominal) and with a total average grade above 8.0. Furthermore, my thesis was rewarded with grade 9.0, resulting in a "cum laude" pass.

awards.title: Bachelor's degree (nominal, cum laude)
awards.description: All courses of the bachelor's programme of Aerospace Engineering were passed at first attempt, in the assigned time (nominal) and with a total average grade above 8.0 ("cum laude").

awards.title: P-in-1 (cum laude)
awards.description: P-in-1 indicates the student has passed all first-year courses within the assigned time of a single year. Furthermore, the results of all exams taken average out to a grade higher than 8.0 ("cum laude").

awards.title: Beste profielwerkstuk (Best graduation project)
awards.description: I was rewarded for best graduation project 2011. I investigated the purification of water through micro-organisms ("Waterzuivering"). This research was performed at the water purification facility in Stroe, The Netherlands. Reporting was under the guidance of W. van der Welle.

projects.title: Confidential research project with industry partner (V)
projects.description: Supporting technical role in a wind farm control consultancy project with a large industry partner. My responsibilities include the development of a dynamic simulation environment, and advising on controller synthesis and field experiment design.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

projects.title: U.S. National Offshore Wind Research project on the US offshore wind farms
projects.description: The U.S. National Offshore Wind Research & Development Consortium (NOWRDC) focuses on the analysis of future US offshore wind farms. My responsibilities included the analysis of historical data of three European offshore wind farms (supported by Shell and OWEZ), engineering model validation, mesoscale simulation data analysis, and dissemination.

projects.description: Technical lead on a wind farm control consultancy project with a large industry partner. My responsibilities include stakeholder management, historical data analysis, controller design, and field experiment design.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

projects.title: Master's thesis on wind farm modeling
projects.description: Master's thesis under the supervision of prof. Van Wingerden. This research was performed at the University of Colorado Boulder (United States), with local supervision of prof.dr. L.Y. Pao. This work was rewarded the grade 9.0.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

projects.title: Confidential research project with an industry partner (II)
projects.description: Helped to spark interest, plan and execute a consultancy project with a large industrial partner. This project enabled me to improve my soft skills such as project planning, team coordination, and how to have interdisciplinary discussions, as well as improve my understanding of the relevant challenges in the research field.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

projects.title: European Horizon 2020 project: Closed-Loop Wind Farm Control (CL-Windcon)
projects.description: This project addresses the advanced modeling and the synthesis of open- and closed-loop control algorithms for a wind farm by treating the entire farm as a comprehensive real-time optimization problem. The synthesized control solutions will be validated leveraging high-fidelity data from simulation, scaled wind tunnel experiments, and field testing. My main responsibilities include the development of the open- and closed-loop control algorithms, and their validation using data made available by the partners.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

projects.title: Confidential research project with an industry partner (I)
projects.description: During my PhD, I was subcontracted by the U.S. National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) to work in a confidential research project for an industrial partner. For this, I spent two months at the National Wind Technology Center in Boulder, Colorado. This collaboration not only strengthened the link between TUDelft and NREL, but also gave practical insights that have allowed me to tailor my research to better meet the needs of industry.

contributors.headline: Offshore Wind Researcher at Shell | Control Engineer

profile_positions.description:
As a postdoctoral researcher in the wind farm control group, my technical tasks included wind farm yield analysis, wind farm model development and validation, wind farm controller design, software engineering, and consultancy work with leading industry partners on novel wind farm control methods, covering the areas of field experiment planning, implementation assistance, monitoring, analysis and dissemination.

I was the technical lead for 2 industry consultancy projects on wind farm control, and had a supporting role in a third industry consultancy project. My responsibilities included managing stakeholders, SCADA data analysis, model validation, yield analysis, practical implementation, field experiment design, and documentation.

Additionally, I have been the lead engineer for historical data analysis and validation of various engineering models to historical data of three large offshore wind farms. This resulted in two journal publications.

Further, I took a lead role for several wind-energy-control-themed sessions at conferences and online platforms to facilitate a platform for scientific discussion, provide a spotlight for new researchers in the field, and to stimulate interinstitutional and international collaboration.

I also co-led the NREL employee resource group focused on international affinity, cultural acceptance and diversity. My tasks included shaping the mission statement in collaboration with NREL leadership, defining group roles and chairs, and organizing social events.

Finally, during my first year at NREL, I have mentored a Ph.D. student from the Technical University of Munich working on wind farm flow modeling and control.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.location: Delft Center for Systems and Control (DCSC)
profile_positions.description: Tasks included continuation of doctoral research, dissemination, and training new doctoral candidates in the group.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral & Guest Researcher

profile_positions.location: Delft Center for Systems and Control (DCSC)
profile_positions.description:
My doctoral research was on the topic of wind farm control, with a focus on dynamic and closed-loop methods. During my Ph.D., I achieved the following:

The article on which I was the lead author was the first in literature to demonstrate a full-scale wake steering field experiment in Europe. My responsibilities included model validation, historical data analysis, controller design, practical implementation, and experiment monitoring.

Additionally, I, with co-authors, was the first in literature to demonstrate a model-based closed-loop wind farm control strategy in high-fidelity simulation. Tasks included developing a wind farm control framework for the simulation environment, closed-loop controller design, devising and performing various large-eddy simulations.

I am an inventor on patent on the ``Helix'' method for wind farm control. Patent is issued, published, maintained.

I have been the co-lead engineer for wind farm control consultancy project with large industry partner. Also, I was subcontracted by NREL for a wind farm control consultancy project with large industry partner.

I have successfully received two grants. I had a lead role in writing the proposal for the European FLOATECH project, with a budget of € 4.3M. I had a supporting role the proposal for the European WindConners project, with a budget of € 1.5M.

I received the ``Excellent Young Doctor'' award from the European Academy for Wind Energy. Received IEEE Excellent Student Paper Award. Received PhD Best Poster Award by the TUDelft Energy Initiative.

Finally, I had a lead role in the ``3mE PhD Council'' that facilitates events for approximately PhD students of the Faculty of Mechanical, Maritime and Materials Engineering. This council enables people to learn, connect, and improve their PhD experience at the university. Responsibilities included organizing monthly lunch lectures, a 4-week meditation workshop, and an annual sports day.
profile_positions.title: Ph.D. Candidate

profile_positions.description: Subcontracted by NREL to work on an industry consultancy project in the area of wind farm control.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher
